title: Barack Obama Warns Progressives Not to Form ‘Circular Firing Squad’
content:
Businessmen, each and every one. Farmers have to have knowledge of what products to raise and sell, lawyers sell their services, etc. They all had to be intelligent, know how to sell, whether produce, personal services, or how to put together a government. The government is a business. It hires, fires, makes profits, funds foreign countries (charities) produces, regulates, enforces. the people (workers) rely on the government (company) to continue supplying a living. If the government (company) fails, the people/workers fail. That is just a few things a business and the government have in common.
We have free and low income clinics for those who cannot afford health insurance. It is funded thru medicaid. The clinics have access to free medications from big pharma. For instance, the company that makes lantus (insulin) will supply patients with it for free. There is also programs like 'Extra Help' that pays the out of pocket costs of medication for elders on limited incomes. All these programs are free for the asking and proof that the patient is unable to afford the medication and the doctor has prescribed it.

title: Boeing 737 Max 8 Problems
content: 4,129 Boeing 737 Max 8 Problems "The planemaker said last week it would submit final paperwork for the revamp to the Federal Aviation Administration by March 29 to make the system -- known as MCAS -- less aggressive in pushing down a planes nose, and to add redundancy so that its less likely to activate when other systems malfunction. Now Boeing says the update wont be ready until the coming weeks. An issue with integrating the software fix and the planes existing flight-control architecture came to light as Boeing did a final audit of the upgrade, according to a person briefed on the work. Ensuring that MCAS will perform as desired while not interfering with existing flight controls isnt expected to be a significant challenge said the person, who wasnt authorized to speak about the work and asked not to be identified." What was the MCAS fix in January, 2019? Why didn't the MCAS disengage when pilots followed the Boing protocol to cancel the MCAS? How did the Nose Down self-generated computer commands override manual control input? How many versions of the Boeing 737 need to be upgraded? //

title: The making of an American terrorist
content: 4/6/19 ROJ CAMP, Syria  Hoda Muthana is pushing a stroller in the middle of a conflict zone here and if there's a textbook example of extremism, this probably isn't it. That's partly because of what is in Muthana's arms: Adam, her 18-month-old son. Hes a cute kid. Bright brown eyes, like his mom. His tiny hooded coat is emblazoned with patterns of elephants in profile. Some are upside down. What Adam couldn't know is that his mom abandoned the comforts of a suburban American life for one of the world's most barbaric terror organizations. The Trump administration believes Muthana, 24, born in New Jersey and raised in Alabama, is too big a threat to the United States to return. "They dont seem to want to understand what happened in my life that led me to this depraved path. I didnt just wake up in the morning and decide to join the most horrendous jihadist group in history," Muthana said, speaking to USA TODAY from the camp in northern Syria where she has been detained by a U.S.-backed Kurdish militia since last year amid the collapse of the Islamic State group's self-proclaimed caliphate. Muthana snuck off to Syria in 2014 at age 19. She married Islamic State, or ISIS, fighters and exhorted her fellow Americans to commit mass murder and terror attacks. She now is at the center of a political, legal and diplomatic firestorm that carries far-reaching implications for the way the U.S. confronts Americans who join extremist groups. Muthana used to be devoted to a terrorist organization known for beheadings and other gruesome violence, which they recorded for recruitment videos. She helped circulate these videos on social media. Now she wants to return to the U.S. with Adam, whom she conceived with one of the ISIS fighters she married in Syria  and outlived. But there is a major obstacle in her way: President Donald Trump. The president does not want to let Muthana come back to the U.S., even though she has expressed remorse for her actions and is willing to face the U.S. justice system and near-certain jail time. "Her mother wont speak of her," said Charles Swift, a Texas-based civil rights attorney who is representing Hoda Muthana's father. The State Department's attorneys have until mid-April to respond to the family's lawsuit, and the judge could decide the case this summer. At Roj Camp, Muthana fears ISIS sympathizers may try to harm her for disowning the terrorists. "I dont feel safe. I expect retaliation from any side," she said. Bring Muthana back to the United States and charge her with "material support of terrorism". American citizen John Walker Lindh (captured in Afghanistan) was sentenced to 20 years/no parole in 2002 after being found guilty under a similar charge (10 counts).

title: If Socialized Medicine is so "great", why did Mick Jagger come to the US for his heart surgery?

Jump to page: Results 31 to 36 of 36 Posts 48,464 Re: If Socialized Medicine is so "great", why did Mick Jagger come to the US for his heart surgery? Originally Posted by RabidAlpaca If, for arguments sake, we said the US had the most "top in their field" doctors in the world, what good would that do the general populace if only the ultra rich can afford him? What matters is the care that the average American can receive, and in that regard we're nowhere near the top. Tens of millions of Americans can't see a doctor at all, and tens of millions more go financially bankrupt when they're sick or injured. Quality of care varies wildly between rural and city clinics. America has the most rationed healthcare in the industrialized world. Literal death panels at insurance companies decide if someone gets treatment or not. Compare me and my brother, a tale of two equally educated engineers. He lives in the US and pays about 500 USD a month for health insurance and has a $5,000 deductible and can be rejected for arbitrary reasons. I pay about 400 USD a month in Germany for full coverage for my entire family including dental, I can't be denied care for any reason, I have no deductible and essentially no out of pocket costs, and statistically I will live longer and have better healthcare outcomes. Why do you celebrate a healthcare system that costs over twice what every other industrialized nations pay and yet is consistently ranked low in all of the metrics that matter? they do it because right wing propaganda tells them to. i used to do the same thing. Posts 4,862 Re: If Socialized Medicine is so "great", why did Mick Jagger come to the US for his heart surgery? Originally Posted by PeteEU And Americans are going to Mexico and Canada for cheaper care.. you really want to continue down this road? Don't forget vacations to India combined with medical procedures. Never let your sense of morals get in the way of doing what's right. I nominate Grok for worst poster of the year. He doesn't bother to fact check anything. Numerous threads were thoroughly discredited after a few replies. Posts 5,403 Re: If Socialized Medicine is so "great", why did Mick Jagger come to the US for his heart surgery? Originally Posted by Grokmaster Crossing the Border for Care Frustrated by long waits, some Canadians are heading to the U.S. for medical treatment. Canadians seek treatment abroad The Fraser Institute, a Canadian public policy think tank, estimates that 52,513 Canadians received non-emergency medical treatment in the U.S. and other countries in 2014, a 25 percent jump from the roughly 41,838 who sought medical care abroad the previous year. Canadians could expect to wait 9.8 weeks for medically necessary treatment after seeing a specialist in 2014, the researchers found, three weeks more than the time physicians considered to be clinically "reasonable." Ontario, the country's most populous province, provides a good example. The three hospitals that use stem-cell therapy to treat patients with blood disorders and aggressive cancers like the one that Sharon Shamblaw battled are unable to keep up with the soaring demand. So patients are sent to medical facilities in Buffalo, Cleveland, Ohio, and Detroit, Michigan, for the potentially life-saving treatment. Sen. Rand Paul Joins Rising Number of Americans Going Abroad for Healthcare The senator isn’t the only American traveling north across the border in search of lower cost or specialized medical care. Contrast Canada’s system to that of the United States, where Americans are covered by a mix of private and government insurance programs, with 13.7 percent having no coverage at all as of the fourth quarter of 2018. U.S. government data suggests that 150,000 to 320,000 Americans travel abroad each year for medical care , what’s known as medical tourism. Other estimates put it at 1.4 million each year See? You seem to think no healthcare is better than healthcare. Is that right? Last edited by JustHanging; Today at 04:34 PM . Jeez, did you do really do something that stupid? You were as Dumb As Donald!

title: Dems Have Vastly More to Fear from Full Mueller Report than GOP (UPDATED)
content: Re: Dems Have Vastly More to Fear from Full Mueller Report than GOP (UPDATED) Originally Posted by KAG2020 Dems Have Vastly More to Fear from Full Mueller Report than GOP (UPDATED) Dems Have Vastly More to Fear from Full Mueller Report than GOP (UPDATED) | Roger L. Simon QUOTE: Judiciary Chairman Jerrold Nadler is huffing and puffing away about his committee's subpoena-in-waiting lest Attorney General William Barr not be sufficiently forthcoming about the details of the Mueller Report. “But if we cannot reach an accommodation, then we will have no choice but to issue subpoenas for these materials,” Nadler warned. "And if the department still refuses, then it should be up to a judge — not the president or his political appointee — to decide whether or not it is appropriate for the committee to review the complete record.” Methinks the chairman doth protest too much. In other words, it's all a charade for the faithful. He doesn't really want to do anything. Likely Nadler is secretly praying Barr redacts the whole damn thing or ties things up in the courts for long enough for the investigation to disappear at least somewhat down the memory hole. ME: The premise of this article is this one line, "The full text of the Mueller report is a booby-trap for the Democrats." Read the whole article if you have an open mind. If you are a moron then don't read it. Yeah, that must be why Barr is in such a hurry to get out the report.

title: Officials forced way in to Stephen Moore home after failure to pay ex-wife debts
content: Re: Officials forced way in to Stephen Moore home after failure to pay ex-wife debts Originally Posted by HumblePi People that are insecure about themselves, for whatever reason, would rather attack others calling them 'elitists' or 'deep state'. The reasons that Trump base may feel they've been left behind are not our problem it's their problem for allowing themselves to be left behind. If people aren't happy with their circumstances, whether it's their economical or educational situation and feel they have a lack of opportunities, then it's on them to change those circumstances and not simply blame others for it. You don't like what you do for a living? Change it. Take classes, seek out re-training programs, work another job to pay for community colleges or trade schools. Life yourself and your life up and stop expecting others to do it for you or continue putting blame on those people that have done exactly that. My state is filled with people that came from Ohio, Pennsylvania, Virginia and other states where coal mines shut down or advances in technology and robotics put them our of a job. These people got out of those fields and into new fields of work by applying for free re-training programs offered by the state and funded in part by federal funds. Now they're no longer dependent on coal mines or other jobs that have disappeared. Now they're not crying about their situations and how unfair it is and how Trump will bring back 'beautiful clean coal' or promise jobs in industries that have already changed gears and don't need those people any longer. Just stop blaming everyone else for your own situations and take charge of your own lives. You got that evidence of President Trump committing a crime? Still waiting on that. Just stop blaming everyone else for your own situations and take charge of your own lives. That's rich coming from a Liberal. Originally Posted by HenryChinaski You people are my problem. Youre a major component of whats wrong with this country. It's more important to be morally right than factually correct - Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez

title: Barr overstepped his authority
content: General Political Discussion Barr overstepped his authority This is a political forum that is non-biased/non-partisan and treats every persons position on topics equally. This debate forum is not aligned to any political party. In today's politics , many ideas are split between and even within all the political parties. Often we find ourselves agreeing on one platform but some topics break our mold. We are here to discuss them in a civil political debate. If this is your first visit to our political forums, be sure to check out the FAQ and RULES . Registering for debate politics is necessary before posting. Register today to participate and remove the ads - it's free! Re: Barr overstepped his authority Originally Posted by Rogue Valley Barr overstepped his authority and undermined the integrity of the Mueller investigation AG Barr works for Donald Trump, an employer strongly resistant to transparency. Red: The crux of of the current contretemps. There is no provision in the special counsel rules which provide Barr with the independence and the power to make a determination of guilt, or a lack of sufficient evidence to prove guilt. Barr's task was to provide Congress with a written summary of Mueller's conclusions ... not to interpret those conclusions. Keeping in mind the anti-Mueller investigation memo that Barr shared with the White House previous to his appointment as Attorney General overseeing the Mueller investigation, it becomes clear that Barr entered the office with a documented bias against confirming any [Trump] obstruction of justice. The sensible remedy here is to have an independent judge cull the 400 page Mueller Report of the most sensitive classified information, and make determinations on what passages, if any, constitute protected "executive privilege" conversations. Then release what remains to Congress (or the public domain). Rubbish. The regulations governing the special counsel appointment state: At the conclusion of the Special Counsel's work, he or she shall provide the Attorney General with a confidential report explaining the prosecution or declination decisions reached by the Special Counsel. Notice that the explanation is confidential, only for the AG. Moreover, the policy of the DOJ is not speak publicly about the evidence against uncharged persons. (You might recall it was a criticism by Democrats against Comey in the Hillary email scandal.) And there are 6e restrictions as well as national security restrictions. So if you are saying that Barr was TOO open, and should have provided nothing to anyone...you may be right.

title: Why War ****s People Up
content: General Political Discussion Why War ****s People Up This is a political forum that is non-biased/non-partisan and treats every persons position on topics equally. This debate forum is not aligned to any political party. In today's politics , many ideas are split between and even within all the political parties. Often we find ourselves agreeing on one platform but some topics break our mold. We are here to discuss them in a civil political debate. If this is your first visit to our political forums, be sure to check out the FAQ and RULES . Registering for debate politics is necessary before posting. Register today to participate and remove the ads - it's free! Re: Why War ****s People Up Originally Posted by HumblePi Has anyone ever questioned the reasons that all the men and women that returned home from Europe after WWI or those returning from the South Pacific or Europe after WW2 didn't seem to have the same PTSD as those returning from Vietnam, Afghanistan or Iraq? Of course, some game home from both world wars suffering some type of anxiety disorder but as many as 30% of Vietnam veterans have been diagnosed with some sort of anxiety disorder or PTSD. Here's some glaring differences between those who returned from one of the two World Wars, and those returning from Vietnam. Let's talk about drugs that the U.S. provided soldiers in Vietnam to use. According to a 1971 report by the Department of Defense, 51 percent of the armed forces had smoked marijuana, 31 percent had used psychedelics, such as LSD, mescaline and psilocybin mushrooms, and an additional 28 percent had taken hard drugs, such as cocaine and heroin. Okay so, there's that. But that doesn't explain the other cases resulting from conflicts like the Gulf War, Iraq and Afghanistan. Here's the part where everyone is going to jump all over my opinion and tell me I'm wrong, that we had to go to war there because of 9/11 or to take out a dictator like Saddam Hussein in Iraq. My point is that these were not wars. These were not formal wars with patriotic purposes that our men and women were sent to die for that where we were fighting against despotic, deranged men like Hitler and Mussolini, men guilty of crimes against humanity. Iraq, Afghanistan, Vietnam are political wars, those that our government chose to send our military to die for their own agenda which was primarily control of oil fields or oil routes. It's always about the oil, that's just a fact, that's where the basis for any U.S. military involvement in the Middle East stems from. Soldiers don't care if they die for a valid patriotic cause, but losing limbs or eyesight, or bombing civilians in order to protect oil is what causes so much stress that these men and women simply can't cope with it. The fact is, our servicemen have not fought in a real war with a common purpose since WW2. Not Korea, not Vietnam, not Iraq - none of them was a real war fought to control communism or oppression of dictators. And that right there is the difference. Nobody joins the military assuming that if they're sent to fight overseas that they're going to come back all ****ed up. The U.S. ****ed up by involving ourselves in the business of other countries, destabilized their governments, and created more enemies like ISIS and Al Qaeda which only arose after our invasion of Iraq. Why do we even wonder why they hate the U.S. so much? I want to say that US soldiers were not exposed to the worst horrors of WW1. No, the people who watched everyone die where the French and Germans. Russians too, but to a lesser extent. By the time the US showed up, the worst of the trench fighting was over. Same applies to WW2. With the exception of D-Day and the islands of the Pacific, US troops showed up at the end of that game too. And, I suspect most of the PTSD from those days was buried under the rug, as well. Nam, not so much. That war was all out and never ended, at least not well. We also killed the enemy at a 40:1 ratio there. So, mowing down humans was an every day occurrence there, for a decade. Iraq? Maybe the stress of not knowing who the enemy was, the "accidental" killing of civilians and constant threat of IED took its toll. Also, of course, better diagnosis played a part. The stupidity on the Right is legion, surpassed only by the ignorance. - Calamity 2019

title: Not only humans are mummified - New facts have discovered in ancient Egypt tombs
content:
1 2 3 4 5 Not only humans are mummified - New facts have discovered in ancient Egypt tombs A- A A+
Mummified mice are among the artefacts discovered in a decorated tomb recently unearthed near the Egyptian town of Sohag.
The mice and other animals surrounded two mummified human bodies and the burial chamber contains detailed paintings of funeral processions and people working in the fields.
Experts say the tomb is more than 2,000 years old and is thought to be the resting place of a senior official called Tutu and his wife. It was discovered in October when smugglers were caught illegally digging for artefacts.
The Egyptian government's antiquities ministry hopes the finds will draw visitors to the desert town 390km (242 miles) south of Cairo, near the Nile.
Mostafa Waziri, the secretary general of Egypt's supreme council of antiquities, said it was a "beautiful, colourful tomb" and "one of the most exciting discoveries ever in the area". Since the 2011 uprising, the country's political instability and insecurity has hit the tourism industry. The ministry hopes this new attraction will help draw visitors back.
A mummified woman and boy dating back to the Ptolemaic era were put on display outside the tomb. The woman is thought to have been aged between 35 and 50 when she died while the boy was 12 to 14.
More than 50 mummified mice, cats and birds were also unearthed.
Here, an archaeologist examines a carefully wrapped falcon.
Among the treasures found inside the tomb were fragments of painted, decorative faces.
The antiquities ministry said the presentation of this newly uncovered tomb was intended to "draw the world's attention to the civilisation and antiquities of Egypt".
Report a mistake by marking it and pressing Ctrl+Enter

title: Pinkerton: Making American Healthcare Great Again
content: Everyone has healthcare, world class healthcare and it's free. Just go to an emergency room and you have to be treated by law. We're talking about health INSURANCE. Successful insurance models exist in the auto insurance industry. (1) health insurances compete across state lines. (2) Flexible, individualized buffet style insurance for coverages one wants. (3) Tiered pricing, (a) catastrophic, (b) family economy, (c) gold plated. (4) pooled risk for pre-existing conditions. (5) Family members claimed as a dependent of tax returns can be included on parents insurance for as long as they are dependents. Let competition do the rest.
